Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Numerical Simulations of Black Holes, Neutron Stars and Gravitational Radiation
Award.AbstractNarration:
Einstein's theory of general relativity describes all gravitational interactions in the universe, ranging from the force that pulls a falling apple to the Earth, to the expansion of the Universe itself. The equations of general relativity - called Einstein's equations - are sufficiently complex so that they can be solved exactly only under very special circumstances. To understand the merger of two black holes, for example, and to predict the signals that we hope to observe soon with the LIGO gravitational wave observatory, requires computer simulations. This award supports research efforts aimed at developing methods and approaches for such computer simulations. In particular, the focus is on methods that are well suited for the self-consistent treatment of the gravitational forces in supernova explosions. These extremely energetic explosions play an important role in the evolution of the universe, even the development of life, lead to the formation of black holes or neutron stars, and yet we still lack a detailed understanding of the explosion mechanism.

The scientific goals of this research effort in numerical relativity include the development and implementation of numerical algorithms for the solution of Einstein's equations of general relativity, as well as their application in the numerical modeling of relativistic objects, in particular neutron stars and black holes. The focus of this work is methods in spherical polar coordinates, which have distinct advantages over Cartesian coordinates for many applications, including gravitational collapse, accretion disks, and supernova calculations. This is done in collaboration with colleagues at the Max-Planck-Institute for Astrophysics in Garching, Germany, on including these methods in relativistic astrophysics simulations with a state-of-the-art treatment of microphysical phenomena. Among the long-term goals are supernova simulations that adopt both these advanced microphysics methods and a self-consistent treatment of relativistic gravitational fields. These results will advance our understanding of these processes and will predict their observational signatures in neutrino, electromagnetic and gravitational wave signals. The latter will be important for the new generation of gravitational wave laser interferometers, including the Laser Interferometer Gravitational wave Observatory (LIGO).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Einstein’s theory of general relativity describes gravitation.  It describes all gravitational interactions, ranging from the gravitational forces we feel on the Earth, to the evolution and fate of the Universe itself.  It predicts objects and phenomena as exotic as black holes and gravitational waves — both of which were confirmed spectacularly when LIGO detected, for the first time, gravitational waves from two colliding black holes in 2015.  

 

Learning about such objects and phenomena, and the interactions between them, requires solving Einstein’s equations, a complicated set of differential equations that form the core of general relativity.  For some simple cases these differential equations can be solved analytically, i.e. with pencil and paper, but for more general cases this is not possible.  In the field of “numerical relativity” we instead solve the equations numerically, by writing computer programs that help us model black holes and other relativistic objects on the computer.   Numerical relativity experienced a remarkable breakthrough in 2005, when it became possible to simulate two back holes that orbit each other and then collide and merge.  

 

During my entire career, my research has been focussed on developing approaches and methods that aid in the numerical solution of Einstein’s equations, and the application of these methods to model astrophysical objects with strong gravitational fields, in particular black holes and neutron stars.  During the funding period of this grant I have made significant progress in several different areas.

 

I have further developed methods for numerical relativity in spherical coordinates.  To date, most numerical relativity codes, including those used in the “break-through” calculations mentioned above, use so-called Cartesian coordinates x, y and z —think of space as a three-dimensional chess-board, in which the coordinates label each cube.  For many applications, however, it is more natural to use spherical coordinates, r, θ and φ.  A familiar example is the Earth, on which latitude and longitude play the role of θ and φ.  These coordinates also feature some pathologies, however — for example, the poles on the Earth do not correspond to a unique value of the longitude.  Dealing with these so-called coordinate singularities has hampered the implementation of numerical relativity in spherical coordinates — at least in the absence of any symmetries — for a long time.  During the previous funding period, collaborators of mine and I introduced new techniques that avoids these problems, and we have further developed these techniques with support from this grant.  Moreover, we have now implemented these methods in publicly available codes, so that they can be used broadly by anybody in the numerical relativity community and beyond.

 

I have also used this code to study so-called critical phenomena in gravitational collapse — phenomena that appear at the threshold of black-hole formation, and that reflect remarkable properties of Einstein’s theory.  Discovered originally in 1993 by Matt Choptuik, most studies of critical phenomena (with some notable exceptions) have been limited to spherical symmetry.  My new code in spherical coordinates is ideally suited to relax the assumption of spherical symmetry, and to study effects that appear only in the absence of spherical symmetry.  Specifically, my collaborators and I studied critical phenomena in the presence of rotation and other aspherical deformations — showing that angular momentum behaves similar to mass, generalizing results for non-rotating black holes to those with rotation, confirming earlier perturbative calculations, and establishing how generic, i.e. general, these phenomena are.

 

Many current numerical relativity simulations of black holes use a so-called “moving-puncture” technique that renders the black holes in a very special way, in what we now call a “trumpet geometry”.  Gaining analytical insights into these geometries has dramatically helped our understanding and interpretation of the numerical simulations.   Over the funding period of this project, my collaborators and I have advanced our understanding of trumpet geometries in several ways.  Most importantly, we have been able to develop a notion of these geometries in the absence of spherical symmetry, and to derive analytical expressions describing trumpet geometries for rotating black holes.   

 

Support from this grant has also allowed me to work with several undergraduate students, for whom involvement in a research project complements their in-class education.  These research projects result in interesting new results, and some from the funding period of this grant (on the stability of supermassive stars, and on black-hole accretion expressed in trumpet geometries) have been published in peer-reviewed journals already, with students as lead-authors.
